characters: DOWN WITH THE BLOODY RED QUEEN
THE DRAPERIES IF YOU MUST BUT CLOTHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warm light shines from the study of the gracious Kingsley home. A man, silhouetted in the window, speaks with ardor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES KINGSLEY has just described his new venture to hi friends, including LORD ASCOT.

dialogues.speaker: LORD ASCOT
dialogues.text: Charles, you have finally lost your senses.

dialogues.speaker: A COLLEAGUE
dialogues.text: This venture is impossible.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: For some. Gentlemen, the only way to achieve the impossible is to believe it is possible.

dialogues.speaker: A COLLEAGUE
dialogues.text: That kind of thinking could ruin you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: I’m willing to take that chance. Imagine trading posts in Rangoon, Bangkok, Jakarta... He stops. His nine year-old daughter ALICE stands at the door in her nightgown, clearly frightened. He goes to her CHARLES KINGSLEY (CONT’D) The nightmare again? She nods. He takes her hand and turns to his guests. CHARLES KINGSLEY (CONT’D) I won’t be long. INT. YOUNG ALICE’S BEDROOM - LATER 3 He sits on her bed, listening with utmost seriousness.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’m falling down a dark hole, then I see strange creatures...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: What kind of creatures? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 2.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well, there’s a dodo bird, a rabbit in a waistcoat, a smiling cat...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know cats could smile.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Neither did I. Oh, and there’s a blue caterpillar.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Blue caterpillar. Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Do you think I’ve gone round the bend? He feels her forehead as if for a fever.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: I’m afraid so. You’re mad. Bonkers. off your head. But I’1l tell you a secret...all the best people are. She smiles and leans against him. CHARLES KINGSLEY (CONT’D) It’s only a dream, Alice. Nothing can harm you there. But if you get too frightened, you can always wake up. Like this. He pinches her. She screams and pinches him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A horse-drawn carriage careens down the road at a full gallop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALICE KINGSLEY is on the verge of womanhood, beautiful, b slightly off-kilter. She sees the world with different ey than other people her age. Presently, she’s tired and gru as her mother fusses with her wild mane of blonde hair.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Must we go? I doubt they’1ll notice if we never arrive. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 3.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: They will notice. She re-ties her waist sash, feeling for her corset. HELEN KINGSLEY (CONT’D) Where’s your corset? She pulls back her dress to see bare legs. HELEN KINGSLEY (CONT’D) And no stockings!

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’m against them.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: But you’re not properly dressed.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Who’s to say what is proper? What if it was agreed that “proper” was wearing a codfish on your head? Would you wear it?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Alice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: To me a corset is like a codfish.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Please. Not today. Frustrated, Alice looks out the window and mutters.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Father would have laughed. She sees the hurt on her mother’s face and instantly regr her words. ALICE (CONT’D) I’m sorry. I’m tired. I didn’t sleep well last night. Her mother pats her hand in a forgiving gesture.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Did you have bad dreams again? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 4.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Only one. It’s always the same ever since I can remember. Do you think that’s normal? Don’t most people have different dreams? Alice’s mother removes her own jewelry and puts it on her

dialogues.speaker: HELEN KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. There! You're beautiful. Now, can you manage a smile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garden party is in full swing. Everyone has turned ou in their summer finery. Guests play croquet on the great lawn. Skiffs drift lazily on a meandering river. Alice approaches LORD and LADY ASCOT with a fixed unnatur smile. Lord Ascot is a stately, aristocratic man. Lady Ascot is red-faced with annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: LADY ASCOT
dialogues.text: At last! We thought you’d never arrive. Alice, Hamish is waiting to dance with you. Go! She pushes Alice off and turns on Helen. LADY ASCOT (CONT’D) You do realize it’s well past four! Now everything will have to be rushed through!

dialogues.speaker: HELEN KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: I am sorry. We...

dialogues.speaker: LADY ASCOT
dialogues.text: Never mind! She rushes off.

dialogues.speaker: LORD ASCOT
dialogues.text: Forgive my wife. She’s been planning this affair for the last twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: If only Charles were here... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 5.

dialogues.speaker: LORD ASCOT
dialogues.text: My condolences, madame. I think of your husband often. He was truly a man of vision.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LORD ASCOT
dialogues.text: I hope you don’t think I have taken advantage of your misfortune.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Of course not. I’m pleased that you've purchased the company.

dialogues.speaker: LORD ASCOT
dialogues.text: I was a fool for not investing in his mad venture when I had the chance. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Charles thought so too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice does a line dance with HAMISH who takes after his mother, refined and immaculate with aristocratic arroganc

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hamish, do you ever tire of the Quadrille?

dialogues.speaker: HAMISH
dialogues.text: On the contrary. I find it invigorating. He struts like a peacock. Alice laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HAMISH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do I amuse you?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No. I had a sudden vision of all the ladies in top hats and the men wearing bonnets. He doesn’t even crack a smile. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 6.

dialogues.speaker: HAMISH
dialogues.text: It would be best to keep your visions to yourself. When in doubt, remain silent. Alice’s smile fades. Without her father, she feels there’ no one like her in the whole world. They dance on. Alice sees a flock of geese overhead. Distracted, she bumps int the dancers in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: HAMISH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pardon us! Miss Kingsley is distracted today. (to Alice) Where is your head?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I was wondering what it would be like to fly.

dialogues.speaker: HAMISH
dialogues.text: Why would you waste your time thinking about such an impossible thing?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Why wouldn’t I? My father said he sometimes believed in six impossible things before breakfast. She laughs at the memory. Hamish looks pained. He sees hi mother nearby. She waves him on impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: HAMISH
dialogues.text: Meet me under the gazebo in precisely ten minutes. He goes off. Suddenly two giggling girls appear in front Alice. It’s the Chattaways.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We have a secret to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: If you’re telling me, then it’s not much of a secret.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Perhaps we shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We decided we should! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 7.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: If we tell her, she won’t be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Will you be surprised?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Not if you tell me. But now you've brought it up, you have to.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No we don’t.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: In fact, we won't.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I wonder if your mother knows that you two swim naked in the Havershim’s pond.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You wouldn't!

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh, but I would. There’s your mother now. Alice starts to walk toward her. Fiona blurts out.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Hamish is going to ask for your hand! Alice stops dead. Her sister, MARGARET, suddenly pulls he away.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You’ve ruined the surprise! (to Alice) I could strangle them! Everyone went to so much effort to keep the secret.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Does everyone know?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: It’s why they’ve all come. This is your engagement party. Hamish will ask you under the gazebo. When you say “yes”... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 8.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: But I don’t know if I want to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Who then? You won’t do better than a Lord. She looks at Hamish who blows his nose, studies the conte of his kerchief, then folds it and puts it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You'll soon be twenty, Alice. That pretty face won’t last forever. You don’t want to end up like Aunt Imogene. They look at their middle-aged AUNT IMOGENE with over-rou cheeks and a yellowing white dress that’s too young for h

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: And you don’t want to be a burden on mother, do you?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: So you will marry Hamish. You will be as happy as I am with Lowell and your life will be perfect. It’s already decided. Lady Ascot's face suddenly looms in hers.

dialogues.speaker: LADY ASCOT
dialogues.text: Alice dear, shall we take a leisurely stroll through the garden? Just you and me? She jerks her away quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Ascot steers her through the gardens at a fast clip.

dialogues.speaker: LADY ASCOT
dialogues.text: Do you know what I’ve always dreaded?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: The decline of the aristocracy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 9.

dialogues.speaker: LADY ASCOT
dialogues.text: Ugly grandchildren. But you’re so lovely. You’re bound to produce little... (she gasps) Imbeciles! The gardeners planted white roses when I specifically asked for red!

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You could always paint the roses red. Lady Ascot looks at her strangely.

dialogues.speaker: LADY ASCOT
dialogues.text: What an odd thing to say. Come along. She hurries her along the path. Alice hears a jingling so

dialogues.speaker: LADY ASCOT
dialogues.text: You should know that my son has extremely delicate digestion... Alice sees SOMETHING LARGE AND WHITE dart past.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Did you see that?

dialogues.speaker: LADY ASCOT
dialogues.text: See what?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It was a rabbit, I think.

dialogues.speaker: LADY ASCOT
dialogues.text: Nasty things. I do enjoy setting the dogs on them. Don’t dawdle. She rushes Alice toward the gazebo. Alice looks for the rabbit. LADY ASCOT (CONT’D) If you serve Hamish the wrong foods, he could get a blockage. And there it is, a LARGE WHITE RABBIT in a waistcoat, standing on its hind legs and staring directly at Alice. blinks. The White Rabbit darts behind a tree.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Did you see it that time? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 10.

dialogues.speaker: LADY ASCOT
dialogues.text: See what?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: The rabbit!

dialogues.speaker: LADY ASCOT
dialogues.text: Don’t shout! Pay attention. Hamish said you were easily distracted. What was I saying?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hamish has a blockage. I couldn’t be more interested, but you’ll have to excuse me. Alice dives into the wooded area off the path and stands a moment, mind reeling. A hand lands on her shoulder. She jumps.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Aunt Imogene! I think I’m going mad. I keep seeing a rabbit in a waistcoat.

dialogues.speaker: IMOGENE
dialogues.text: How very strange. What kind of waistcoat?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Brocade, I think. What does it matter? It’s a rabbit in a waistcoat!

dialogues.speaker: IMOGENE
dialogues.text: I can’t be bothered with your fancy rabbit now. I’m waiting for my fiance.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You have a fiance? The White Rabbit darts by. ALICE (CONT’D) There! Did you see it?

dialogues.speaker: IMOGENE
dialogues.text: He’s a prince. But, alas he cannot marry me unless he renounces his throne. Isn’t it tragic?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Very. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 11.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She backs away and runs into her sister’s husband, LOWELL kissing a strange woman. The woman runs off.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Lowell?

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: Alice. We were...Hattie is an old friend.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I can see you’re very close. Lowell is bright red and highly flustered.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: You won’t mention this to your sister, will you?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’m confused. I need time to think.

dialogues.speaker: LOWELL
dialogues.text: Think of Margaret. She would never trust me again. You don’t want to ruin her marriage, do you?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Me? I’m not the one... Suddenly Hamish is there, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: HAMISH
dialogues.text: There you are! I told you meet me under the gazebo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her under the gazebo. The shadows of the pillars fall on her like prison bars. She glances at a string quartet discreetly positioned in the shadows... bows pois Hamish drops to his knee. Alice notices an artist immortalizing the moment.

dialogues.speaker: HAMISH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alice Kingsley...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hamish. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 12.

dialogues.speaker: HAMISH
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You have a caterpillar on your shoulder. He frantically brushes at his shoulder. ALICE (CONT’D) Don’t hurt it. Alice lets the CATERPILLAR crawl onto her finger, then pl it gently onto a tree branch.

dialogues.speaker: HAMISH
dialogues.text: You’1l want to wash that finger. He sees his mother motioning to him from below. Everyone watching. He blurts out.

dialogues.speaker: HAMISH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alice Kingsley, will you be my wife? The question hangs in the air. Unsure of herself, unsure her future, unsure of her own sanity in that moment, Alic stammers.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I...IT....e well, everyone expects me to...and you’re a Lord...and my face won’t last...and I don’t want to end up like...but this is happening so quickly...I think...I...I... She sees the WHITE RABBIT leaning against a pillar, glari at her with undisguised impatience. ALICE (CONT’D) ...need a moment. She turns and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She follows the White Rabbit across a meadow.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Wait! She loses sight of him. She peeks over the hedgerow. No rabbit. Stumped, she looks around. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 12 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 13.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A white paw reaches up and grasps her by the ankle. With quick jerk, it pulls her down into the rabbit hole. She screams...

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE RABBIT HOLE 11
dialogues.text: .--and keeps screaming as she tumbles head over heels dow the hole. She frantically grabs at the walls which are hu with paintings, ancient maps, cracked mirrors, demonic ma etc. She pulls out books, jam jars, a crystal ball, a bad claw, a monkey’s hand and a human skull in her frantic ef to stop herself. And down she falls. It begins to grow da as the day passes into night. And still she falls. Finall after what seems like hours...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAM! She hits bottom, smacking her head on a wooden floo

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Ah! Wind knocked out, she gasps for air, then she sits up, rubbing the bump on her forehead. She’s in a round hall w many doors. She gets up and tries a door. It’s locked. Sh tries another one and another. She knocks. ALICE (CONT’D) Hello? Hello! Anyone there? No answer. She moves around the hall. Every door locked. She sees a three-legged glass table with a small key sitt on top. She picks up the key and tries it in a door. It’s too small for the lock. She tries it in a few doors, too small. She comes upon a curtain and pulls it aside to reveal a little door about feet high. She tries the key in the door. It fits. She opens the little door and bends down to look through to the other s

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE SMALL DOOR
dialogues.text: She sees a garden with a fountain. She tries to fit throu the door, but her shoulders get stuck. She pulls back. Stumped, she goes back to the table and replaces the key. But now there’s a bottle on the table. She looks for the person who put it there. ALICE (CONT’D) Is someone here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 13 14 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 14.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks at a label. “DRINK ME”. She sniffs the contents recoils, then shrugs. ALICE (CONT’D) It’s only a dream. She takes a drink, shudders, gags and coughs from the tas In a moment, she notices that the table is getting larger ALICE (CONT’D) That’s curious. Alice SHRINKS to two feet high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors loom above her. She takes a step and trips on h now-oversized clothes. Dragging them behind, she tries to open the door. But it’s still locked. She groans as she realizes what she’s done. She goes back to the glass tabl where she can see the gold key sitting on top.

dialogues.speaker: ON ALICE
dialogues.text: We hear VOICES as they watch Alice through a keyhole.

dialogues.speaker: DODO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You'd think she would remember this from the first time.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You've brought the wrong Alice.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She's the right one. I’m certain of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice attempts to climb the table leg, but gets tangled i her too-big clothes and slides off. She notices a little under the table. She looks around for the unseen person.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: If this is some sort of prank, I am not amused! She opens the box. It’s a cake with “EAT ME” written out ornate icing. She considers, looks up at the key high abo on the table. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 15 16 17 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 15.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She takes a tiny taste of the cake. She takes another bit WHOOSH! She shoots upward rapidly. Her clothes fit again, but she keeps growing. Buttons pop, seams are strained an her skirt gets shorter. The ceiling gets closer...her hea grazes it! She stops. Relieved, she bends down and picks the gold key. Crouching, she goes to the little door and fits the key in the lock.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She's the wrong Alice.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Give her a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs at herself and goes back to the table. She pic up the little bottle and takes another swallow, shivers a the taste, then shrinks again to two feet high. Dragging too-big clothes, she runs to the door, puts the key in th lock, opens it and steps through. EXT. A GARDEN IN UNDERLAND — DAY 17 She enters a fantastical world. Underland is bizarre, illogical, often dangerous, absurd, and strangely beautif The garden is brown and tangled, its statues broken and overgrown. The mossy fountain is silent. Alice hears a bellow/sneezing sound as a GREEN PIG dashes past. The TAL FLOWERS have gaunt, haunted HUMAN FACES. SHABBY, THIN BIR walk on stalk legs. DRAGONFLIES, HORSEFLIES and ENORMOUS GNATS do fierce battle in the sky above.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Curiouser and curiouser.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: I told you she's the right Alice. She turns to see a DODO BIRD with eye glasses and a walki stick, the WHITE RABBIT, a young female DORMOUSE in breec and two round BOYS with their arms thrown over each other shoulders, Dee and Dum are stitched on their collars.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: I am not convinced. The White Rabbit throws up his hands. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 16.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: How is that for gratitude? I've been up there for weeks trailing one Alice after the next! And I was almost eaten by other animals! Can you imagine? They go about entirely unclothed and they do their...shukm in public. I had to avert my eyes. The FLOWERS WITH HUMAN FACES study Alice.

dialogues.speaker: TALKING FLOWER
dialogues.text: She doesn't look anything like herself.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: That's because she's the wrong Alice.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: And if she was, she might be.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: But if she isn't, she ain't.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: But if she were so, she would be.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: But she isn't. Nohow.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How can I be the “wrong Alice" when it's my dream? And who are you, if I May ask. Dee shakes her hand, speaking very fast.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: I'm Tweedleehe's Tweedledum.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: Contrariwise. I'mTweedledum he 'sTweedledee.

dialogues.speaker: DODO
dialogues.text: We should consult Absolem.

dialogues.speaker: TALKING FLOWER
dialogues.text: Exactly. Absolem will know who she is. Tweedledee puts out his arm to her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 17.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: I'll escort you. Dum pulls her away from Dee.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: It's not being your turn. They tug her between them.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: Leave off!

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: Let go!

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Are they always this way?

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: Family trait. (to Tweedles) You can both escort her. Dee takes one arm. Dum takes the other and ALICE, THE TWEEDLES, THE DODO, WHITE RABBIT and DORMOUSE start off. HUMAN-FACED FLOWERS gossip about Alice as they pass.

dialogues.speaker: TALKING FLOWERS
dialogues.text: It can't be her. She looks nothing like Alice. She is not even wearing the right dress.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Who is this Absolem?

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: He's wise. He's absolute.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWEEDLES
dialogues.text: He's Absolem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter a forest of tall mushrooms surrounded by mist.

dialogues.speaker: THE CATERPILLAR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who are you? Alice can see a form ahead where the mist rises in a stea plume. It’s coming from a hookah. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 19 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 18.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There’s a BLUE CATERPILLAR smoking it. The White Rabbit pushes Alice toward him.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Absolem?

dialogues.speaker: THE CATERPILLAR
dialogues.text: You’re not Absolem. I’m Absolem. The question is...who are YOU? He blows smoke rings in her face. She coughs.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Alice.

dialogues.speaker: THE CATERPILLAR
dialogues.text: We shall see.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What do you mean by that? I ought to know who I am!

dialogues.speaker: THE CATERPILLAR
dialogues.text: Yes, you ought. Stupid girl. Unroll the Oraculum. The White Rabbit unrolls an ancient PARCHMENT lying on a toadstool.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: “The Oraculum: Being a Calendrical Compendium of Underland.” Alice looks. It’s a timeline depicting the major events o each day. Every day has a title and an illustration.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It’s a calendar.

dialogues.speaker: THE CATERPILLAR
dialogues.text: Compendium. It tells of each and every day since the Beginning.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: Today is Griblig day in the time of the Red Queen. He points to the illustration.

dialogues.speaker: THE ORACULUM 19
dialogues.text: It shows all of them, including Alice, peering at the Oraculum, at that exact moment.  20 21 22 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 19.

dialogues.speaker: THE CATERPILLAR
dialogues.text: Show her the Frabjous day. White Rabbit turns the scroll further into the future.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: Frabjous being the day you slay the Jabberwocky.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Sorry? Slay the...what?

dialogues.speaker: THE ORACULUM
dialogues.text: The illustration is animated. The Jabberwocky is tall as dinosaur with reptilian wings, scales, long sharp claws, pronged tail and a vest. It hisses! A Knight with long blonde hair in chain mail fights him with a shining sword

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That being you there with the Vorpal sword.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No other swords can kill the Jabberwocky. Nohow.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If it ain’t Vorpal, he ain’t dead. As she swings the sword, she reveals her face to the read The girl is unmistakably Alice, with bloodlust in her eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice backs away.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: That’s not me.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: I know!

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: Resolve this for us, Absolem. Is she the right Alice? The CATERPILLAR looks Alice in the eye. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 20.

dialogues.speaker: THE CATERPILLAR
dialogues.text: Not Hardly. He blows smoke, obliterating himself from view.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: I told you!

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: Oh dear!

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: I said so.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: No, I said so.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: Contrariwise, you said she might be.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: No. You said she would be if she was.

dialogues.speaker: THE FLOWERS
dialogues.text: Little imposter! Pretending to be Alice! She should be ashamed!

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: I was so certain of you. They all glare at her as if it is somehow her fault.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I don’t mean to be the wrong Alice. Wait, this is my dream. I’m going to wake up now and you'll all disappear. She closes her eyes and pinches herself. She opens them again. The animals are still there. ALICE (CONT’D) That’s curious. She pinches herself again. The animals just look at her. ALICE (CONT’D) Pinching usually does the trick. The Dormouse pulls a long sharp hat pin from her scabbard (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 23 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 21.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: I could stick you if that would help.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It might actually. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: My pleasure. She stabs her in the ankle with relish. Alice yelps. But instead of a small sound, a THUNDEROUS ROAR is heard and BANDERSNATCH smashes through a high wall.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: Bandersnatch! It has a huge furry body with the head of a rabid bulldog Drool oozes from his squashed muzzle. His fur is caked wi blood and filth. His teeth are shark like and broken, stained with blood. A foul stench emanates from him. Everyone scatters. But they’re intercepted by RED KNIGHTS wearing the RED QUEEN’S CREST: a heart in flames. The Knights capture the fleeing animals. A PIG and a FLAMINGO caught and thrown into a caged wagon. The Dodo gets away. Knight grabs the White Rabbit by his leg, lifting him up.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: Unhand me! I do not enjoy being... He’s tossed into the caged wagon with the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice runs. The Bandersnatch thunders after her. She stop

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Wait. It’s only a dream. Nothing can hurt me. She turns around to face it. The Dormouse watches from be a tree.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: What is she doing? The Bandersnatch opens its drooling muzzle to eat Alice. ALICE (CONT’D) Can’t hurt me...can’t hurt me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 24 25 26 27 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 22.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: Run, you great lug! The Dormouse groans. She leaps onto the Bandersnatch, pul herself up, hand-over-hand to its shoulder and drives her hatpin into its eye. It bellows! She tries to pull the hatpin out, but the whole eye pops out. Bandersnatch howl and whips around raking Alice’s arm with its long claws. runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large HAND with RED BIRTHMARK reaches down and picks up abandoned Oraculum. The grim KNAVE OF HEARTS, ILOSOVIC STAYNE, has a flaming red birth mark which covers half hi face and hands. He looks through the scroll and sees something that alarms him. He tucks it into his saddle ba and rides away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice runs down the path, but it diverges in two directio A road sign points south to “SNUD” and east to “QUEAST”.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: This way! East to Queast!

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: No, south to Snud! He pulls her one way. Tweedledee pulls her the other. The an ear-slitting SCREECH. The enormous JUBJUB BIRD lands i front of them. It’s part monkey-eating eagle and part ostrich. It makes a “JUB’JUB” sound as it snatches the Tweedles in its claws and takes flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JubJub flies over the barren red earth of Crims with Tweedles in its claws toward Salazen Grum and the castle the Red Queen on the shore of the Crimsen sea. Her flag w the Heart in Flames flies atop the spires. INT. THE RED QUEEN’S GREAT HALL/THRONE ROOM - DAY 27 A long hall is lined with FROG FOOTMEN with A FISH BUTLER The RED QUEEN'S angry scream comes from behind closed doo The doors bang open to reveal IRACEBETH the RED QUEEN. Sh has a huge oversized head, extremely large features, and bright red hair. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 23.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Someone stole three of my tarts! She leans into the face of a frog.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you steal them?

dialogues.speaker: FOOTFROG
dialogues.text: No, your Majesty. She walks the row, studying the face of each frog. At the end, she whirls to leer into the face of one terrified fr

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Did you steal my tarts?

dialogues.speaker: FOOTFROG
dialogues.text: No, Your Majesty. She wipes a telltale bit of jam from the side of its mout She holds her finger up and sniffs the juice.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Squimberry juice.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTFROG
dialogues.text: I was so hungry!

dialogues.speaker: OFF WITH HIS HEAD
dialogues.text: Red Knights converge on the guilty Frog.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTFROG
dialogues.text: No! Please! I have little ones to look after! The Knights drag him out. The Queen turns to the Fish But

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Go to his house and collect the little ones. I love tadpoles on toast points almost as much as I love caviar. The Fish butler suppresses his revulsion and anger.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Majesty? The Queen’s face lights up to see him. She turns flirty. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 24.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Ilosovic Stayne...you knave, where have you been lurking? She holds out her hand. He kisses it, barely. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Majesty, I found the Oraculum. He lays it on a table and rolls it out.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: That? It looks so ordinary for an oracle.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Look here. On the Frabjous Day. He points to the illustration of Alice in the scroll.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: I'd know that tangled mess of hair anywhere. Is it Alice?

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: I believe it is.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: What is she doing with my darling Jabberwocky?

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: She appears to be slaying it.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: She killed my Jabberbabywocky!

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Not yet. But it will happen if we don’t stop her.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Find Alice, Stayne. Find her!

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: I will bring her head and lay it at your feet.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: No. Bring the whole girl. I want to do it myself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 25.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stayne sits on his horse as the Knights hold a growling BLOODHOUND, BAYARD, bound by a spiked collar and heavy ro

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Find the scent of human girl and earn your freedom.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODHOUND
dialogues.text: For my wife and pups as well?

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Everyone goes home. He puts his nose to the ground and leads the Knights off. Stayne strokes his horse’s neck. STAYNE’S HORSE Dogs will believe anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still running, Alice stops to look at the gashes on her a

dialogues.speaker: CHESHIRE CAT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It looks like you ran afoul of something with wicked claws. She sees the disembodied head of a CAT hovering midair.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: And I'm still dreaming!

dialogues.speaker: CHESHIRE CAT
dialogues.text: What did that to you?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Banner or Bander...

dialogues.speaker: CHESHIRE CAT
dialogues.text: The Bandersnatch? I’d better have a look. The Cat disappears then reappears as a whole cat. CHESSUR all calm, casual sensuality with a seductive grin. He inspects the wound, then tries to lick it.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What are you doing? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 30 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 26.

dialogues.speaker: CHESHIRE CAT
dialogues.text: It needs to be purified by someone with evaporating skills or it will fester and putrefy.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I‘1ll be fine as soon as I wake up.

dialogues.speaker: CHESHIRE CAT
dialogues.text: At least let me bind it for you. She allows him to use his handkerchief to bind the wound.

dialogues.speaker: CHESHIRE CAT
dialogues.text: What do you call yourself?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Alice.

dialogues.speaker: CHESHIRE CAT
dialogues.text: The Alice?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’m not going into that again!

dialogues.speaker: CHESIRE CAT
dialogues.text: I never get involved in politics. You'd best be on your way.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What way? All I want to do is wake up from this dream!

dialogues.speaker: CHESHIRE CAT
dialogues.text: Fine. I’1l take you to the Hare and the Hatter. But that’s the end of it. He disappears suddenly. She looks around. He reappears ahead. CHESHIRE CAT (CONT’D) Coming? There’s nothing else for her to do but follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is part hare/part house. The chimneys are ears. roof is thatched with fur. The picket fence is rabbit fee doorknob a bunny tail. The windows are pink rabbit eyes t look round and blink. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 27.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The tea party has been going on for years. The tea set is odd admixture of cracked pots and chipped cups. The tablecloth is stained and threadbare, the chairs lopsided The MAD HATTER slumps in one of them, staring into space, pale and morose. Even his clothes reflect his gloomy mood always wears a ragged and scorched TOP HAT. Paranoid and anxious, the MARCH HARE constantly wrings his paws and lo ears. The Dormouse has arrived ahead of Alice. She wears Bandersnatch eye at her waist. The Hare/house taps the Ma Hare on his head.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH HARE
dialogues.text: What? Where? Who’s there? The Cheshire Cat strolls in with Alice. At sight of her, Hatter bolts upright. He brightens, his clothes even perk Transfixed, he moves towards her, shortest route being ac the top of the table. He comes close, studying her intent

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Your hair wants cutting... It’s you.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: No, it’s not. McTwisp brought us the wrong Alice.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: It’s absolutely Alice. You're absolutely Alice! I’d know you anywhere. I’d know him anywhere. He takes her hand and pulls her back over the top of the table. She tries not to step on any teacups. He plunks he down in the chair next to his.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Well, as you can see we’re still having tea. It’s all because I was obliged to kill Time waiting for your return. You're terribly late, you know... naughty. Well anyway, time became quite offended and stopped altogether. Not a tick ever since.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Time can be funny in dreams.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Yes yes, of course. But now you are back, you see, and we need to get on to the Frabjous day. I’m investigating things that begin with the letter M. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 27A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MAD HATTER (cont'd) Have you any idea why a raven is like a writing desk? Hare, Hatter and Dormouse clasp their hands high.

dialogues.speaker: HATTER/HARE /DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: Downal wyth Bluddy Behg Hid! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 28.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: CHESHIRE CAT
dialogues.text: “Down with the Bloody Big Head”. Bloody Big Head being the Red Queen.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: It’s a secret language used by us... the Underland Underground Resistance!

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Come, come. We simply must commence * with the slaying and such... (to Time) Therefore, it’s high time for Time to * forgive and forget. Or forget and * forgive, whichever comes first. Or, is * in any case, most convenient. I’m * waiting. * The March Hare taps his watch, listens to it, dips it int his tea cup, listens again.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH HARE
dialogues.text: It’s ticking again! The Cat puts his tea cup down with disgust.

dialogues.speaker: CHESIRE CAT
dialogues.text: All this talk of blood and slaying has put me off my tea.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: The entire world is falling to ruin * and poor Chessur’s off his tea.

dialogues.speaker: CHESIRE CAT
dialogues.text: What happened that day was not my fault! Suddenly enraged, the Hatter slams both hands on the tabl Cups and teapots go flying.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: You ran out on them to save your own skin! (cursing in Outlandish) You guddler's scuttish pilgar lickering... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 28A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Cheshire Cat puts his paws over Alice’s ears. The Hat keeps cursing faster and faster. He can’t stop himself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 29.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: .--Shukem juggling sluking ur-pals. Bar lom muck egg brimni.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: Hatter! The Hatter jerks. He pulls himself back to the moment.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: (Fez ??) Thank you. I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: CHESIRE CAT
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with you, Tarrant? You used to be the life of the party. You used to do the best Futterwacken in all of Witzend.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Futter...?

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: It’s a dance.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: On the Frabjous day, when the White Queen once again wears the crown, again. On that day, I'll Futterwacken... Vigorously. They glare at each other like estranged brothers. The Hare/House taps March Hare on the shoulder again.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH HARE
dialogues.text: What? The Knave! Hide her! Cheshire Cat disappears. Hatter picks up a small bottle.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Drink this.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh no... They force the liquid down her. She shrinks to six inches high. They shove her into the teapot and cram her now ove large clothes in behind her. The Hatter closes the lid.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Mind your head.  31 32 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dim inside, except for a stream of light from the sp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hatter does a headstand in his chair. The Dormouse climbs into a soup tureen. The Hare lays on the table. Following his nose, Bloodhound leads Stayne and two RED KNIGHTS in.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Well, if it’s not my favorite trio of lunatics.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH HARE
dialogues.text: You’re all late for tea! The March Hare throws a teapot at them.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: We're looking for the girl called Alice. The Bloodhound sniffs around the table.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Speaking of the Queen...here’s a song we sang at her soiree.

dialogues.speaker: HARE /HATTER/DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: Twinkle Twinkle Little Bat! How I wonder where you’re at! Stayne grabs the Hatter around the neck. Knight #1 cracks Hare with his weapon. Knight #2 pours hot tea on the Dormouse’s head.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: If you’re hiding her, you’ll lose your heads.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Already lost them. All sing together.

dialogues.speaker: HARE /HATTER/DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: Up Above the World you fly, Like a tea tray in the sky. They all laugh crazily.  33 34 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 31. INT. THE TEAPOT - ALICE’S POV 33 Alice peeks out the spout. Hare, Hatter and Dormouse sing despite being hit, choked and dunked.

dialogues.speaker: HARE /HATTER/DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: Twinkle Twinkle Twinkle Twinkle! The Bloodhound puts its paws on the table, sniffing Alice teapot. The Hatter takes a chance. He whispers to him.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Downal with Bloody Behg Hid. The Bloodhound stops dead. Hatter shoots a look at the teapot. The Bloodhound drops to the ground and sniffs, pretending to catch a new trail.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Follow the Bloodhound. The Knights go off. Stayne lingers suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: You’re all mad. Hare/Hatter/Dormouse laugh hysterically. The Knave goes o The Hare and Dormouse stop laughing, but the Hatter’s laughter goes on...and on.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: Hatter! He jerks and drags himself back from the edge of hysteria

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Really, I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts the teapot lid, but closes it again.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Sorry... one moment... He takes a pair of milliner’s scissors from his pocket an quickly whips up a miniature ensemble for Alice out of th tea cozy, a doily and a swatch of her old dress. He lifts the lid again and hands it to her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 32.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Try this on for size. He closes the lid again to give her privacy. In a moment, there’s a tiny knock on the lid. He opens it and helps he out in her remade clothes.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Hum... Sorry, it’s the best I could do * I'm afraid. Not half bad. *

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: Good thing the Bloodhound is one of us or you'd be... She draws her finger across her throat ominously.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH HARE
dialogues.text: Best take her to Marmoreal. She’1l be * safe with the White Queen. *

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Can she help me wake up?

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: If she doesn’t put you to sleep. * He sweeps his hat off and puts it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Your carriage, m’ lady.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: The hat?

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Anyone can go by horse or rail. But the absolute best way to travel is by * Hat. Oohh... I’ve just made a rhyme. * Alice sits on it, nervous and unsure, of the Hat and the Hatter. The Dormouse sits on it too, shoving Alice over.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mally... Just Alice. * She climbs off, annoyed. The Hatter puts his hat on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 33.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Fairfarren all! They start off. Dormouse watches them go jealously.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH HARE
dialogues.text: But you haven’t had your tea!

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Mind your head. * A teapot hurtles toward them. Alice ducks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice hangs on tight as the Hatter walks at a jaunty pace

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: ‘Twas brillig, and the slithy toves Did gyre and gimble in the wabe: All mimsy were the borogoves, And the mome raths outgrabe. She hops down to his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Sorry? What was that?

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Sorry? What was what? The Jabberwock with eyes of flame. The jaws that bite. The claws that catch. Beware of the Jabberwock, my son. And the frumious Bandersnatch. He took his vorpal sword in hand. The vorpal blade went snicker-snack. He left it dead, and with its head. And he went galumping back. It’s all about you, you know...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’m not slaying anything. I don’t slay. So put it out of your mind.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Mmm. ..mind. * He drops her to the ground and walks on. She follows.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Wait. You can’t leave me here! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 33A.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: You don’t slay... Do you have any idea what the Red Queen has done? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 34.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MAD HATTER (cont'd) (mimicking her) You “don’t slay”

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I couldn't if I wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: (accusing) You’re not the same as you were before. You were much more...much more muchier...you’ve lost your muchness.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: My muchness? He pokes her in the stomach with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: In there. Something’s missing. He walks away again. She frowns, then runs after him.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Tell me what Red Queen has done.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: It’s not a pretty story.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Tell me anyway. He picks her up, plunks her back on his shoulder and push through the foliage which becomes blackened and twisted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come to a place where the ground is scorched and bar His voice goes hoarse with emotion as he begins the tale.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: I was Hatter to the Queen at the time. The Hightopp clan have always been employed at court. His narration fades and WE SEE the story unfold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hatter stands with his clan: the Hightopps. Every one adults and children, wear top hats. The mood is festive. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 38 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 35.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The White Queen sits on her white horse with other member her court, including the White Rabbit, March Hare, Cheshi Cat. The White Knight holds the shining Vorpal Sword. The woods turn dark as enormous leathery wings block the Faces fill with awe as they watch the fearsome creature. Knight, stunned by its magnitude, drops the sword and fle Panic ensues. People run as the Jabberwocky shoots fire a them. The Queen's horse rears. The Hatter grabs the reins and leads her to safety. He looks back. White Rabbit help others escape. The March Hare looks up, shocked into paralysis. The Cheshire Cat hovers near to the Hightopp c who stand together to protect the children. But as the Jabberwocky descends upon them, the Cat disappears. The Knave picks up the fallen Sword. He lifts it victoriously and the Jabberwocky retreats. A moment later, the Hatter returns to the scene, face fil with shock and horror at the place where his clan took th stand. The earth still smolders. Only one burned and tram Hat remains. He tosses his own hat away, picks up the bur one, brushes the soot off and places it firmly on his hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is deeply moved. She looks up at the scorched Hat h still wears, then to his tormented face. He twitches, dri to the edge of madness by guilt, helpless rage and deep l

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hatter? Hatter! He jerks and pulls himself back from the abyss.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Just fine Really.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Did you hear that? I’m certain I heard something.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (nervously) Voices? He looks back at the dark woods. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 39 40 41 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 36.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Red Knights! They hear the BAY of the bloodhound. He puts Alice into h breast pocket and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hatter dodges trees and leaps over stumps. He sees th edge of the woods ahead. But there’s a flash of RED throu the trees. He turns. A Red Knight steps out. He turns the other way, another Red Knight. They’re surrounded. Eyeing them warily, he whispers to Alice.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Go south to Grampas Bluffs. The White Queen’s castle is just beyond. The Hatter sweeps his hat off as if in a conciliatory ges to the approaching Knights. He whispers to Alice. MAD HATTER (CONT’D) Jump on the hat. Now. She takes a leap onto the Hat. The Hatter flings his arms wide, sending the Hat and Alice sailing over the treetops MAD HATTER (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: DOWN WITH THE BLOODY RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: She clings to the brim of the Hat as it sails out of the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hat lands in the soft grass. Alice looks back at the forest, and then south toward gently rolling hills. It’s getting dark and there are strange night sounds out there She slips under the relative safety of the hat for the ni

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice wakens to the SOUND OF SOMETHING LARGE SNIFFING out the hat. She sits up. Suddenly, the Hat is flipped over, exposing her. She closes eyes for the end. A BIG WET NOSE sniffs her. She opens her eyes. It’s the Bloodhound, BAYA

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You turncoat! You were supposed to lead them away! The Hatter trusted you! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 37.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLOODHOUND
dialogues.text: They have my wife and pups. That information does little to lessen her anger.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: THE BLOODHOUND
dialogues.text: Bayard.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Sit! He cocks his head and looks down at her curiously.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: sit! He sits, amused if nothing else. Something occurs to him.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLOODHOUND
dialogues.text: Would your name be “Alice” by any chance?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes, but I’m not that one.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLOODHOUND
dialogues.text: The Hatter would not have given himself up for just any Alice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Where did they take him?

dialogues.speaker: THE BLOODHOUND
dialogues.text: To the Red Queen’s castle at Salazun Grum. She looks at his worn hat, remembering the pain in his ey

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: We're going to rescue him.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLOODHOUND
dialogues.text: That is not foretold.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I don’t care. He wouldn’t be there if it weren’t for me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 42 43 44 45 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 38.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLOODHOUND
dialogues.text: The Frabjous Day is almost upon us. You must prepare to meet the Jabberwocky.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I have had quite enough! Since the moment I fell down that rabbit hole, I’ve been told what I must do and who I must be. I’ve been shrunk, stretched, scratched and stuffed into a teapot. I’ve been accused of being Alice and of not being Alice. But this is my dream! I’11 decide how it goes from here.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLOODHOUND
dialogues.text: If you diverge from the path...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I make the path! She’s so commanding, he lies down at her feet. She climbs his long ear and sits on his shoulders. ALICE (CONT’D) Take me to Salazen Grum. And don’t forget the Hat. The Bloodhound picks up the Hat in his teeth and runs. Al hangs onto his spike collar to keep her seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bayard wades through viscous red mud with Alice on his ba He holds his head high to keep the Hat out of the mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bayard races across the red desert to Salazen Grum and th dark castle that sits on the tempestuous shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walls are high and foreboding with a surrounding moat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach the moat and they see large lumpish objects which appear to be the heads of the executed. They look around for a way across. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 46 47 48 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 39.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: THE BLOODHOUND (CONT’D) There’s only one way across. Alice looks at the grim moat. She takes a deep breath for courage.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Lost my muchness have I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She jumps onto one of the floating heads, then crosses th moat by jumping from head to head. Reaching the other sid she vomits onto the ground. She looks up at the impossibly high wall, then sees a sma cracked opening near the ground...just wide enough for a inch girl. She squeezes through it. In a moment, her head reappears. She calls across to Bayard.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Bayard! The Hat! He picks the Hat up in his teeth, turns in circles like a discus thrower and releases it. The Hat sails high across the moat and over the wall. Bayard BAYS his farewell. EXT. THE QUEEN’S GARDEN - THE BUSHES - DAY - CONT. 47 Alice finds herself in the bushes at the edge of a garden She hears a loud WHACK, a small cry of pain, then cheers laughter. She looks through the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen and her Courtiers play croquet. The Red Queen w her huge head is surrounded by three powdered and painted COURTIERS with equally out-sized body parts: a woman with EXTRA-LARGE NOSE, another with LONG HANGING EARS, a man w a HUGE PROTRUDING BELLY. The Queen swings her mallet. There’s that small cry again Alice looks around for the source. The ball rolls toward and lays, furry and gasping, in the grass. It’s a HEDGEHO tied by its four legs into an awkward ball. Its fur is matted and filthy, its face buried in the grass. THWACK! cries out as it’s hit again. The mallet is a miserable FLAMINGO tied by its feet. The hedgehog rolls to a stop n Alice. She attempts to untie it. It cries out fearfully.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Shhh. I want to help you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 49 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 40.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where’s my ball? Page! Alice frees the hedgehog. It stares at her mutely before stumbling into the foliage. Alice sees two large white fu feet. Her gaze travels up to the White Rabbit, dressed as court page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down at tiny Alice.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: Well! If it isn’t the wrong Alice. What brings you here?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’ve come for two reasons. She beckons him closer. He bends down. She punches him. ALICE (CONT’D) That's for dragging me down here against my will!

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: You didn’t have to hit me! Now there’s going to be a bruise. Is there? He shows her his chin. She looks, indulging him.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: What’s the other reason?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’m going to rescue the Hatter.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: You're not rescuing anyone being the size of a gerbil.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Do you have any of that cake that made me grow before?

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: Upelkuchen? Actually, I might have some left. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 50 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 41.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He digs in his pocket and takes out a large piece of the cake. She takes it and shoves it into her mouth. WHITE RABBIT (CONT’D) Not all of it! Too late. Alice shoots upward. Buttons fly off her torn garments, seams strain and give way. WHITE RABBIT (CONT’D) Oh no, stop! Don’t do that! She grows right out of the shreds of her remaining clothe until she bursts through the bushes...stark raving nude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice looks down at the Red Queen and her courtiers. The tall bushes hide all but her head and shoulders. Everyone stares.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: And WHAT is this? The White Rabbit comes out, improvising like mad.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: It’s a “who”, Majesty. This is...um

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Um?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: From Umbradge.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: What happened to your garments?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I outgrew them. I tower over everyone in Umbradge. They laugh at me. So I’ve come to you, hoping you might understand what it’s like.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: My dear girl. Anyone with a head that large is welcome in my court. The courtiers with their equally out-size body parts laug (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 51 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 42.

dialogues.speaker: THIS ENORMOUS GIRL
dialogues.text: (to Alice) You'll be my new favorite. The Courtiers exchange competitive glances, especially LA LONG EARS. INT. THE RED QUEEN’S CASTLE - GREAT HALL/THRONE ROOM - DA Large Alice, clad in hastily constructed garments, procee with the Queen down the great hall toward the throne room Along with the Footfrogs, MONKEYS hold up tables and chai with their arms and heads. Exhausted BIRDS flap their win to stay aloft with lamps hung from their beaks. The Queen plops down on her ORNATE THRONE. SPIDER MONKEYS serve as legs of the throne. They strain under the weight The Queen kicks off her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: I need a pig here! A small pig hurries over and lays down belly up. She puts her feet on his belly and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love a warm pig belly for my aching feet. (to Alice) Sit! sit! Alice sits, trying to keep her weight off the chair held by monkeys. The Queen waves her hand at the three Courtie

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Go away. The Courtiers go out with dark jealous looks at Alice.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Where are my Fatboys? You must meet them! Fatboys! The Tweedles come in. They’re bound together by a gold be around their waists. Their faces have been painted and powdered with hearts on their cheeks and red heart lips. Their eyes are lowered, downtrodden. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 43.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There they are! Aren’t they adorable? And they have the oddest way of speaking. Speak boys. Amuse us. She kicks Tweedledum.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Speak! Dum lifts his eyes and sees Alice. He nudges Dee.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: Is that being...? Alice lifts a finger to her lips.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: No, it isn’t. Not a bit. But Tweedledum didn’t see Alice’s gesture.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: Contrariwise, I believe it is so...

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: No! It ain’t so. Nohow! He stomps on Dum’s foot to silence him. Dum pinches him. Dee pinches him back. The Queen laughs raucously.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: I love my Fatboys. Now get out. They go out. Stayne enters. The Queen blinks her eyes seductively at him. Stayne represses a shudder.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you are, Stayne. Any luck with the prisoner?

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: He’s stubborn.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: You're too soft. Bring him! The Knights go off. Stayne notices Alice.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: And who is this lovely creature? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 44.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He takes Alice’s hand, looking at her intensely.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Um, my new favorite.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Does she have a name?

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Um.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Yes? Her name?

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: It’s Um!

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: I believe your name has slipped the Queen’s mind. She smacks him.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Her name is UM, you dolt! The Knave reacts with smoldering anger.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: From Umbradge.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Ilosovic Stayne, at your service. He kisses her hand. She pulls it away quickly. The guards drag the Hatter in, chained by hands and feet. The Queen lifts his head by his hair. Alice stifles a gasp. He’s be roughed up. His eyes have an empty far-away stare.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: We know Alice has returned to Underland. Do you know where she is? He doesn’t respond. She claps her hands in front of his f Hatter jerks back to the moment, but doesn’t see Alice.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: I’ve been considering things that begin with the letter “m”’: moron, mutiny, murder, malice... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 45.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Were looking for an “A” word now. Where is Alice? He thinks hard, has an inspiration, changes his mind, re- considers, mulls, then shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Who? That wee little boy? I wouldn’t * know. *

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: What if I take off your head, will you know then? She laughs. The Hatter laughs louder and keeps laughing.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Stop that. He laughs louder in her face. She slaps him. He keeps laughing, madly. The Queen makes a “loco” motion to the others. But when the Hatter sees Alice, the mad laughter stops. Surprised at her new size, he gives her a wry smil He turns to the Queen, smarmy and unctuous.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: My, what a regrettably large head you * have. I should very much like to hat * it.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: Hat it?

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Yes, I used to hat the White Queen, * you know, but there wasn’t very much * for me to work with, poor dear. Her * head is so small.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: It’s tiny, a pimple of a head.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: But this... What I could do with * this, monument, this orb. Nay, this * magnificently heroic globe! *

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: What could you do? He lifts his bound hands helplessly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 45A.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unbind him, Stayne! How can he work if his hands are bound? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 52 53 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 46.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Knave unbinds his hands. Hatter circles the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Shall it be a bonnet or a boater, or * something for the boudoir? (growing manic) A cloche, dunce hat, death cap, coif, snood, barboosh or pugree, , yarmulke, cockle-hat, pork-pie, tam o’shanter, billy-cock, bicorn, tricorn, bandeau, bongrace, fan-tail, night cap, garibaldi, fez... +e * HF Alice pretends to sneeze.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hatter! He jerks back to the moment.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I’m fine. *

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: (to Alice and Stayne) Leave us. The Knave is suspicious of the Hatter. But his interest i Alice draws him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s right behind Alice, breathing down her neck. She tri to move past him, but he grabs her arm with the wound. Sh cries out as he pushes her against the wall. KNAVE OF HEARTS (CONT’D) I like you, Um. I like them large. He leans in for a kiss just as Lady Long Ears passes. She smiles and goes off.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Get away from me! She kicks him and runs. He glares after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bayard crosses the bluffs and approaches the White Queen’ castle.  54 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 46A. INT. THE WHITE QUEEN’S COURTYARD - DAY 54 MIRANA, THE WHITE QUEEN waits for Bayard as he staggers inside. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 55 56 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 47.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE QUEEN
dialogues.text: What news, Bayard?

dialogues.speaker: BAYARD
dialogues.text: Alice has returned to Underland. A smile lights up the Queen’s soft lovely face.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE QUEEN
dialogues.text: Where is she now?

dialogues.speaker: BAYARD
dialogues.text: In Salazun Grum. Forgive me, I allowed her to divert from her destined path.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE QUEEN
dialogues.text: But that is exactly where she will find the Vorpal Sword. We have our champion! Rest now. You’ve done well. Exhausted, he falls to the ground. EXT. THE RED QUEEN’S CASTLE - THE GARDEN 55 Alice searches in the bushes, passing the HEDGEHOG who’s cleaning the caked dirt off his fur.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Ah. The HEDGEHOG watches Alice pick up the Hat. She wipes the mud off and straightens it out with loving care. INT. RED QUEEN’S BED CHAMBER - EVENING 56 The Queen stands at the window.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: You must find Alice, Stayne. Without the Jabberwocky, my sister’s followers will surely rise against me. (bitter) My ugly little sister...why do they adore her and not me? Stayne comes up behind, but does not touch her.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: I cannot fathom it. You are far superior in all ways. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 57 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 48.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: I know. But Mirana can make anyone fall in love with her: men, women, even the furniture. She glances at the captive ANIMALS/FURNITURE.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Even the King. Her dark, bitter gaze travels down to the grim moat below

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: I had to do it. He would have left me.

dialogues.speaker: KNAVE OF HEARTS
dialogues.text: Majesty, isn’t it better to be feared than loved?

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN
dialogues.text: I’m not certain anymore. Oh, let her have the rabble! I don’t need them. I have you. She leans her large head back, her eyes big and dewy.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I do have you, don’t I, Stayne? He manages a smile, but gives her no reply. INT. THE RED QUEEN’S DRESSING ROOM - NIGHT 57 The Hatter hums as he works with ribbons, bows, veils and feathers. Alice enters a room full of huge, colorful hats

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: They’re wonderful! You must let me try one on. He puts a hat on her. She poses like a grand lady. She pu one on him. He poses like a grand lady too. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: It’s good to be working at my trade again.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It’s just a pity you had to make them for her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 49.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Realizing what he’s done, he’s suddenly filled with remor and self-recrimination. His clothes “slump” as well.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: What’s the hatter with me? The * hatter... Mmmmm. Mmmmm, ma, ma. * Fury seizes him. He takes scissors and murderously attack hat, cutting it to shreds, then another and another.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Stop! Stop! She takes his face in her hands, forcing him to look at h

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hatter! Looking into his eyes, she can see the fear in them.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Have you any idea why a raven is like a writing desk? I’m frightened. I don’t like it in here, terribly crowded. Have I gone mad? + eH She feels his forehead, like her father did years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’m afraid so. You’re entirely bonkers. But I’1ll tell you a secret...all the best people are. He straightens his shoulders with pride. His clothes puff

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh, look! Here’s another one. She picks up his hat from behind a box. It’s his very own Hightopp Hatter’s hat. His eyes fill with emotion to see She puts it on his head. ALICE (CONT’D) That’s better. You look yourself again. He’s too overwhelmed to speak. He takes it off and holds to his heart with gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: RED QUEEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hat Man! Where are my hats? I am not a patient monarch! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 49A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her grating voice reminds him of his purpose. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 58 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 50.

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: I’m told she keeps the Vorpoal Sword hidden in the castle. Find it, Alice. Take it to the White Queen. Help us make the world right again. She glances at the long thick chain from his ankle to the wall and considers another use for the sword.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: We'll go to the White Queen together. He takes her hand. There’s a moment between them that mig have been something more if it weren’t for her large size

dialogues.speaker: MAD HATTER
dialogues.text: Why is it you’re always too small or too tall? INT. RED QUEEN’S CASTLE - UPSTAIRS HALL - NIGHT 58 Alice approaches the Tweedles who are stationed on either side of the Queen’s courtroom door.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Tweedles!

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: Alice! They shake her hands vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: Howdoyedo again.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Where’s...?

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: How is it you’re being so great big?

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: She ain't great big. This is how she normal is.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Where’s the...?

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: I’m certain she is smaller when we met. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 59 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 51.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDEE
dialogues.text: She had drank the pishsalver, to get through the door, recall it? She puts her hands over their mouths.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Where’s the Rabbit?

dialogues.speaker: OVER THERES
dialogues.text: They point in opposite directions. INT. RED QUEEN’S CASTLE - A HALL - NIGHT 59 Alice follows the Tweedles. She sees the Dormouse, dresse a chamber maid. She’s whispering with the White Rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: I’m rescuing the Hatter.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I'm rescuing the Hatter. But you can help. He told me that the Vorpal Sword is hidden in the castle. That means someone must have seen it... a footfrog, a chamber mouse, a pigstool, someone! Ask them all! Go! The Tweedles go off. The Dormouse and White Rabbit remain

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: I don’t take orders from big clumsy, galumphing... Alice looms over her. She points imperiously.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Shoo! Humiliated but outsized, the Dormouse stalks off. The Whi Rabbit is still there.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What is it, McTwisp?

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: I know where the Sword is. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 60 61 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 52.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you say so?

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: You'll hit me again.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I won’t hit you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand in front of the stables.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: The Sword’s hidden inside. Alice opens the door. They both react to the stench.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I know that smell. She looks inside the stable.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BANDERSNATCH
dialogues.text: The Bandersnatch lays in his stall with his huge ugly hea its paws. He moans. The socket with the missing eye oozes blood. Alice gasps and closes the door. The White Rabbit ducks to avoid another hit.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’m not going in there! Look what that thing did to my arm. She shows him the wound. It’s larger, very swollen. He ga

dialogues.speaker: WHITE RABBIT
dialogues.text: Dear oh dear! Why haven’t you mentioned this?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t this bad before. He twitches, breathing fast, flapping his paws and faints Alice looks back at the door, considering. INT. QUEEN’S CASTLE - UPSTAIRS HALL - NIGHT 61 Alice sees Mallymkun studying a decorative sword on the w (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 10/28/08 Blue Revised Pages 53.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Mallymkun! Do you still have the Bandersnatch eye?

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: Right here. She hikes up her maid's skirt to reveal her breeches bene The Bandersnatch eye is still at her waist.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I need it. Alice tries to take it. The Dormouse swats her hand away.

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: Get your own!

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I need that eye, Mally. Mallymkun draws her hatpin sword, brandishing it dangerou

dialogues.speaker: THE DORMOUSE
dialogues.text: Come and get it. She’s much much smaller than Alice with a tiny weapon. Al laughs. Mallymkun realizes the absurdity. THE DORMOUSE (CONT’D) Right. She tosses Alice the hatpin and takes the decorative swor from the wall. She runs at Alice with the huge sword.

dialogues.speaker: AHHHHH
dialogues.text: Alice sidesteps her attack, then tentatively stabs at her with the hatpin. The Tweedles arrive and coach Alice.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEDLEDUM
dialogues.text: Thrusting now!
